Battlefield 2042 – Review

At launch, Battlefield 2042 arrived with ambition but stumbled under the weight of its own contradictions. Set in a near-future world ravaged by climate disasters and geopolitical collapse, the game promised a bold reimagining of the iconic franchise: dynamic weather systems, globe-spanning maps, 128-player battles (on supported platforms), and the removal of traditional classes in favor of the Specialist system.

Visually, 2042 is stunning—maps like Orbital (French Guiana) and Discarded (Antarctica) showcase DICE’s mastery of scale and environmental storytelling. The Hazard Zone mode experimented with tactical extraction gameplay, while Portal offered fans a creative sandbox to relive moments from Battlefield 1942, Bad Company 2, and 3.

However, the game launched with significant issues: minimal narrative context, a shallow Specialist system that felt more like reskinned loadouts than meaningful roles, and a glaring absence of features expected in a modern shooter—no campaign, no voice chat at launch, and limited AI support for squad play. Server instability and balancing problems further eroded player trust.

Over the following years, EA and DICE committed to a “Season 0” reset, overhauling core mechanics, reintroducing class-like roles, and improving map design based on community feedback. By 2024, Battlefield 2042 had evolved into a more cohesive and enjoyable experience—but for many, the damage was done.

Verdict: A technically impressive yet deeply flawed entry that struggled to honor its legacy. It’s a game that could have been great—but only became competent long after players had moved on. For die-hard fans willing to forgive its rocky start, 2042 now offers chaotic, large-scale warfare with moments of genuine brilliance. But it remains a cautionary tale about launching too soon and listening too late.

Battlefield 2042 is a first-person shooter developed by DICE and released in 2021. Set in a near-future global conflict, it abandons the series’ historical and modern-war settings for a high-tech battlefield featuring advanced gadgets, dynamic weather, and massive player counts. It was designed to showcase next-generation scale and chaos but launched with significant issues that affected its reception.

The game features 128-player matches on large, open maps, emphasizing vehicle warfare and player freedom. Traditional classes were replaced by a new “Specialist” system, where each character has unique abilities and equipment. This shift aimed to encourage flexibility but diluted team roles, reducing the tactical coordination that defined earlier Battlefield titles.

Core gunplay and movement feel fluid, with improved weapon handling and traversal mechanics. However, balance problems, inconsistent weapon tuning, and erratic hit registration plagued the launch. The map design, while visually impressive, often felt too large and empty, leading to disorganized gameplay and long travel times between engagements.

Graphically, Battlefield 2042 demonstrates the full capability of the Frostbite engine. Massive storms, tornados, and destructible environments create dramatic visual moments. Weather systems and map-changing events deliver spectacle but sometimes interfere with gameplay clarity. Sound design and atmosphere remain strong, maintaining the immersive audio identity of the franchise.

At release, the game lacked a single-player campaign, focusing entirely on multiplayer modes: All-Out Warfare, Hazard Zone, and Portal. All-Out Warfare provides the classic large-scale experience; Hazard Zone blends extraction-style mechanics with tactical objectives; and Portal allows players to create custom matches using assets from Battlefield 1942, Bad Company 2, and Battlefield 3. Portal became a highlight due to its flexibility and nostalgia value.

Performance and stability were major concerns early on, with bugs, UI issues, and server instability dominating launch feedback. Over time, DICE released extensive patches that improved optimization, restored classic class structures, and overhauled maps to increase combat density. The post-launch updates gradually transformed the game into a more stable and coherent experience.

In summary, Battlefield 2042 began as an ambitious but uneven experiment that traded structure for scale. While its launch was rough, consistent updates have made it more enjoyable and closer to the series’ roots. It remains visually stunning and technically impressive, but its design choices divided fans. For players seeking large, chaotic, modern battles with evolving support, it has matured into a solid—if unconventional—entry in the Battlefield series.

I played Battlefield 2042 with a buddy for a few months at launch, and despite the game being extremely buggy and the vehicles being wildly overpowered, that chaos was a big part of the fun. The early experience delivered unpredictable moments and ridiculous vehicle plays that everyone loved, even if it wasn’t polished.

A few months later the patches toned things down. The vehicle changes removed a lot of that launch-era craziness, and while the gunplay was decent, it felt more arcade-like and less true to classic Battlefield roots. After that, I stepped away from the game for about a year.

Coming back right before BF6 released, the game was in a much better place. It felt more balanced, more stable, and surprisingly captured the Battlefield vibe well enough to hold me over until the next game dropped. Overall, Battlefield 2042 became a solid stepping stone for the series—rough start, but it eventually grew into a fun, respectable experience.

**Battlefield 2042 – The Bug-Field Experience**

Battlefield 2042 is basically a huge, shiny warzone held together with duct tape and hope. You’ll clip through walls, get launched into orbit by a friendly vehicle, and watch enemies teleport like they’re speedrunning reality.

And yet… it’s still fun. Explosions everywhere, chaos nonstop, and those moments where everything *actually works* feel incredible.

It’s messy, loud, and sometimes broken—but that’s part of the charm. 8/10, would get killed by a laggy hovercraft again.

[h3]Launch Review[/h3]

Do not buy Battlefield 2042

DICE\EA know how to make a “Battlefield” game.
DICE\EA made trailers that promoted this game.
> DICE\EA inserted all the “only in Battlefield” moments in to the Trailer
DICE\EA knew that this game is missing all of the below features.
DICE\EA still released this.

A lot of the missing features come from a reddit post, I added a list of my "Broken" experiences. I only wanted to use this list to prove my opening statement.
Battlefield 2042 subreddit and Jellyswim_


No offense was intended, I just wanted to leave my review this morning on the cut content and what a poor "Battlefield" this was.

Missing Core Features
> No standard server browser
> Fewer standardized game modes
> Fewer base game maps than any other title (even including portal the map count is only 13)
> No persistent lobbies You have to matchmake after EVERY round
> Fewer in-game assignments None outside of cosmetic unlocks
> Less character customization options (than BF5)
> No profile progress/stats page in the menu
> No battle log/stats tracker for other players
> No global leaderboards
> No end of round assignment progress screen
> No custom emblems
> Fewer achievements
> No medals
> No swelling crescendo of dramatic music near the end of a match. Static Noise does not count
> Less destruction
> Only a small handful of destructible buildings on each map
> No map altering levolution
> No spectator mode
> No permanent community servers (would be useful for clans and events)

Missing from Infantry Gameplay
> Fewer guns Even including all the portal guns, BF4 still had more at launch
> Fewer infantry gadgets
> No manual leaning
> No diving while swimming
> No high wall vaulting
> No crouch sprinting
> No backwards prone
> No explosion knockback
> No rolling after falling from heights
> No ammo or health pickup off teammates
> No scope zeroing
> No thermal optics
> No indirect fire gadgets
> Less anti-tank launchers
> No lock-on launchers The M5 works with the SOFLAM but that requires 2 people
> No AP mines/claymores
> No static weapon emplacements
> No fortification building
> No resupply stations
> No suppression mechanic This one I don't mind but it was a staple and now it is gone

Missing from Vehicles
> Fewer vehicle types Separate vehicle progression per faction even though they are functionally identical.
> No naval vehicles Except I guess the hovercraft technically
> No vehicle gunner direction indicator
> No lock on direction indicator
> No vehicle enter/exit animations
> No tank turret decoupling This was in BF4
> Less vehicle driver/pilot customization options
> No tank zoom customization options
> No tank gunner customization options
> No helicopter gunner secondary weapons
> No separate helicopter/fixed-wing controls
> No control input while looking behind/free looking in aircraft

Missing from Scoring System
> No squad wipe scoring
> No player damage points
> No vehicle damage points
> No vehicle kill assist points
> No headshot bonus
> No long-range kill bonus
> No assist counts as kill bonus
> No squad objective play bonus
> Oversimplified teamplay scoring (i.e. healing a teammate always gives you +5xp rather than the amount of health you give)
> Squad and Teamwork
> No commander
> No special squad call-in abilities
> No squad field upgrades
> No in-game VOIP
> Fewer factions (with almost nothing to give the 2 factions any distinction)
> No cross-team chat
> No "create new squad" option
> No clans
> No view of squadmates while in the spawn screen
> No "Medic incoming" indicator in downed state
> No rank names/icons, just a number.

Missing from UI and Quality of Life
> Less control customization options
> Less UI customization options
> No HUD/icon opacity customization
> No HUD scaling customization options
> No gunsight reticle customization options
> No network performance graph
> No individual player scoreboard
> Less detail in the 'who killed you' screen
> No ultrawide monitor support. Cannot move UI elements to suit screen size
> Very poor friend joining system

BROKEN
> 45 tick rate servers
> Rubberbanding
> Deploy bugs, revive bugs. Downed state bug that prevents you from being revived if you clip through anything. There times where you have no countdown and cannot respawn
> Janky animations
> Performance is horrible on PC. Unplayable framerates from what looks like CPU bottlenecking
> Unlock three different silencers for the same weapon that have no effect on the stats of the weapon
> Exact same attachment on two different guns having an opposite effect
> Hovercrafts are able to scale vertical surfaces, as well as fly in the right circumstances.
> In rare cases, a player will become unable to damage enemies. This player will also lose their nameplate, causing them to appear as hostile to allies. This is fixed by dying and respawning.
> Broken Bullet Registration
> Broken Bullet Spread
> Broken Weapon Balance
> Broken Vehicle Balance

Do not buy this game

I think just like anyone else who has made a recent review of this game, I only have this game because I wanted the Battlefield 6 exclusive items. But do I think this game is good? It's complicated. I don't think it's terrible but it's... meh. Especially after experiencing the BF6 Open Beta, the drastic difference in quality is uncanny. 

This game got so many things wrong and it's sad because in my personal opinion, this is the most interesting concept of a Battlefield game that isn't BF1. Sometimes the game is actually fun to play but most of the time, it feels like a slog. ESPECIALLY because most of the maps are awful. Most of the 64 player maps feel like it was made for 128 people, and the 128 people maps feel like 256 people maps. The maps are just WAY too big. And even if you do get to the enclosed maps like REDACTED (which is my favorite map on this game), the game turns into a glorified Call of Duty which isn't too much of an issue? The bigger issue is that this is a Battlefield game and for a Battlefield game, this is a disappointment.

I can't in full confidence say that this game is worth your time and I feel like if it wasn't for the BF6 exclusive cosmetics, I would feel like I wasted my life which to an extent I did. I appreciate the effort on the devs trying to turn around this mess but the damage was already done. And I am glad they learned their mistakes with this and now BF6 is turning out to be really promising. Though with the new EA deal that happened with the Saudis... it might blow over. Might.

BF2042 was 3 dollars though so it was kind of worth it.
